author: By Michael Wines, Anne Barnard, Sean Keenan, Dave Montgomery and Meghann M. Cuniff
title: ‘Scared and Tired’: Thousands Across the U.S. Rally Against Gun Violence
description: As hundreds of demonstrations unfolded around the country on Saturday, supporters of gun control legislation cried out for action.
content: WASHINGTON — After Uvalde, after Buffalo, after Parkland and Newtown and El Paso and hundreds of other mass shootings over the past two decades, thousands of protesters rallied against gun violence on Saturday in Washington, D.C., and in cities across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: With Lifeguards Scarce, Beach Season Needs Saving
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 11, 2022.
content: “It’s hard to watch. It’s 100 degrees in Texas. If they don’t come to their lifeguarded neighborhood pool, they will find a body of water somewhere.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Josh Peck
title: In Uvalde, a Bishop Makes an Impassioned Plea: Tighten Gun Laws
description: In South Texas, where guns are woven into the culture, Archbishop Gustavo García-Siller is urging his community to reconsider. “We have to!” he says.
content: UVALDE, Texas — The day after an 18-year-old gunman massacred 21 students and teachers at an elementary school, state political leaders expressed fury over the shooting but quickly swatted away the possibility of new gun laws to stem further violence. Archbishop Gustavo García-Siller was listening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Roger Cohen
title: Momentum in Ukraine Is Shifting in Russia’s Favor
description: With the Ukrainians running short of guns and ammunition, and pressures growing on Western governments, Moscow’s fortunes may be rising.
content: A war in Ukraine that began with a Russian debacle as its forces tried and failed to take Kyiv has seemingly begun to turn, with Russia now picking off regional targets, Ukraine lacking the weaponry it needs and Western support for the war effort fraying in the face of rising gas prices and galloping inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Leonard
title: If You Must Point Fingers on Inflation, Here’s Where to Point Them
description: The Fed continues to evade accountability for inflation.
content: As the midterm elections draw nearer, a central conservative narrative is coming into sharp focus: President Joe Biden and the Democratic-controlled Congress have a made a mess of the American economy. Republicans see pure political gold in this year’s slow-motion stock market crash, which seems to be accelerating at the perfect time for a party seeking to regain control of Congress in the fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Just How Burned Out Are Parents?
description: Take this Times test to find out.
content: Lately, I’ve been saying that my level of burnout feels like “Covid of the soul.” Which is to say I mostly feel normal, and that we’ve gradually been able to ease back into the rhythms of our prepandemic life, but there remains a residual exhaustion, partly psychic, that I haven’t had time to fully resolve. There are some days when my alarm goes off and the first thought that occurs to me is: I can’t believe I have to get up and do all the things again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin
title: Howard Schultz: Starbucks Is Battling for the ‘Hearts and Minds’ of Workers
description: Mr. Schultz, the chief executive of Starbucks, discussed the challenges he’s faced since returning to lead the company as it faces rising worker discontent and China’s ever-increasing role in global business.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss and Marie Solis
title: U.S. Gas Prices Hit a New High: $5 a Gallon
description: The unrelenting march higher continues as the average price touches a new milestone, according to AAA.
content: HOUSTON — Gasoline prices reached a grim milestone on Saturday, as the national average for regular gasoline reached $5 a gallon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Who Is the Former TV News Chief Helping the Jan. 6 Committee?
description: James Goldston was a longtime producer at ABC News and then its president for seven years.
content: As news organizations scrambled in 2017 to satisfy the bottomless appetite for information about the new president, James Goldston, the president of ABC News, declared the dawn of “a new golden age” in American journalism, with Donald J. Trump as its improbable catalyst.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh
title: How Long Does Covid Immunity Last? Will a Second Illness Be Worse? How Can I Prepare?
description: Some reinfection questions, answered.
content: If you’re one of the millions of Americans who have already had Covid-19, you may be wondering how long you will have immunity from the coronavirus. Earlier in the pandemic, most people assumed that getting infected had at least one upside: that you would be protected against future encounters with the virus. But as the latest wave heads toward the Western region of the country and the virus shows no signs of easing up, reinfections seem to have become common. Already, many people are reporting second or even third infections with newer variants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: What Is Ramsay Hunt Syndrome?
description: Justin Bieber announced that he had the rare facial condition. Here’s what you need to know about it.
content: On Friday, Justin Bieber announced that he has Ramsay Hunt syndrome, a rare condition that has paralyzed half his face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir and Malin Fezehai
title: ‘We Buried Him and Kept Walking’: Children Die as Somalis Flee Hunger
description: The worst drought in four decades, and a sharp rise in food prices caused by the war in Ukraine, have left almost half of Somalia’s people facing acute food shortages.
content: DOOLOW, Somalia — When her crops failed and her parched goats died, Hirsiyo Mohamed left her home in southwestern Somalia, carrying and coaxing three of her eight children on the long walk across a bare and dusty landscape in temperatures as high as 100 degrees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: How Do I Force My Unresponsive Landlord to Make Needed Repairs?
description: Tenants have a few tools at their disposal when a landlord or management company turns a blind eye. Here’s how to start the process.
content: Q: I live in a rent-stabilized apartment in a medium-size, prewar building in Brooklyn. A couple of months ago, the ceiling in my shower started leaking. Then, a chunk of the ceiling above the leak collapsed. The super covered the hole with cardboard but never actually fixed the leak or ceiling. I have called numerous times, and he always says “tomorrow” but never fixes it. I have also called management twice and sent pictures. The wall seems to be becoming moldy. The cardboard is starting to fall apart. What should I do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aileen Kwun
title: Color, Craft and Comfort at Milan Design Week
description: Trends from the largest global design event, celebrating its 60th year.
content: It’s not a stretch to call Milan Design Week the design world’s largest annual global event. The commercial anchor of the yearly fair is Salone Internazionale del Mobile — the trade show, held this year from June 7 through 12 at the Rho fairgrounds, where design lovers, curators and the industry’s key players convened to discover and unveil the latest product and furniture releases from around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Jan. 6 Panel Puts Focus on Cabinet Discussions About Removing Trump
description: Other reports verify Representative Liz Cheney’s assertion that cabinet members considered using the 25th Amendment to oust Donald Trump after the assault on the Capitol.
content: When Representative Liz Cheney asserted at the House Jan. 6 hearing on Thursday that Trump administration cabinet members weighed invoking the constitutional process to remove President Donald J. Trump from office after the attack on the Capitol by his supporters, she did not immediately provide details or evidence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliane Brum
title: Was a British Journalist the Latest Victim of Bolsonaro’s War on the Amazon?
description: The disappearance of Dom Phillips and Bruno Pereira signals another tipping point in the Amazon.
content: Monday began, for me, with a call that became a horror story. I discovered that Dom Phillips, a British journalist and friend, had disappeared a day earlier in the Javari Valley, one of the Amazon’s most dangerous regions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Woman Gets 5-Year Ban From Grand Teton for False Report on Missing Hiker
description: Heather Mycoskie told investigators she had seen Cian McLaughlin on the day he disappeared. An investigation revealed she had not, the authorities said.
content: A woman accused of providing false information about a missing hiker in Grand Teton National Park has been banned from the park for five years, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: The Phone Booth of the Mind
description: Phone booths may be obsolete, but they still offer a good model for keeping our phones from taking over our lives.
content: A crowd gathered in Times Square recently for the removal of what the city promoted as New York’s last public pay phone. “End of an Era,” declared the news release headline, even though the era when pay phones played any meaningful role in New Yorkers’ lives certainly ended long ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley, Lauren Herstik and Douglas Morino
title: Bill Cosby Team Says Accuser Gave Conflicting Account of ‘Sex Assault’
description: A 2018 essay based on an interview with the accuser, Judy Huth, depicts her encounter with Mr. Cosby in 1975 differently than in her testimony. But Ms. Huth has said the essay is wrong.
content: Bill Cosby’s defense team introduced a former reporter from The National Enquirer at his sexual assault trial in California on Friday, arguing that the reporter’s depiction of Judy Huth’s encounter with Mr. Cosby at the Playboy Mansion starkly contradicted Ms. Huth’s own account from the stand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Edward Wong
title: Biden Races to Expand Coalition Against Russia but Meets Resistance
description: Many Asian, African and Latin American nations are maintaining ties with Russia as the United States tries to isolate President Vladimir V. Putin and end the war in Ukraine.
content: WASHINGTON — Even before the start of the war in Ukraine, an international alliance to rally the world against a Russian invasion came together so quickly that President Biden later marveled at the “purpose and unity found in months that we’d once taken years to accomplish.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Newly United, French Left Hopes to Counter President in Upcoming Vote
description: Left-wing parties have joined forces ahead of France’s two-stage parliamentary elections, hoping to revive their fortunes and put a break on President Emmanuel Macron’s agenda.
content: ALLEX, France — With its centuries-old stone villages nestled among lavender fields, cows and goats grazing in the mountains and miles of vineyards, the Drôme region resembles a France in miniature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Rysman and Clara Vannucci
title: What Would Happen if Fashion Actually Slowed Down?
description: Marco de Vincenzo, the newly appointed creative director of Etro, is not only asking the question, but attempting to answer through action.
content: This article is part of a series examining Responsible Fashion, and innovative efforts to address issues facing the fashion industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Mo Donegal Wins the Belmont, Ending Rich Strike’s Magical Story
description: The favorite at post time, Mo Donegal won by three lengths, becoming the third horse to win a Triple Crown race in 2022. The Kentucky Derby winner Rich Strike was sixth.
content: So, fairy tales do not have legs in horse racing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: DNA Can Now Identify Unknown Soldiers. It Also Reveals Tangles of Old Mistakes.
description: With modern tools, the U.S. military is learning that some unidentified remains from 20th-century battles are those of service members it thought were found and sent home long ago.
content: LEBANON, Tenn. — Growing up in a small Tennessee town, Lane Martin looked every day at the photo of his uncle hanging in the kitchen but knew only a few things about him: He had left Harvard Law School at the start of World War II to join the Marine Corps; he was killed in 1943 storming a Pacific atoll called Tarawa; and his body came home in a gray steel coffin after the war and was buried in a clover-covered family plot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Taggart
title: The Dream of the Open Road Collides With the Reality of $5-a-Gallon Gas
description: Inflation at the diner. Sky-high prices at the pump. The view of the country from a 5,000-mile car journey is clear: It’s expensive out there.
content: Gas prices have risen nearly every day since our trip began on May 12. According to AAA’s tracker, the national average hit $5 a gallon on Saturday. We had no choice but to adapt to the high prices, and in retrospect I think that was for the best. Instead of hitting museums and cool restaurants and the big cities of the Southeast — inflation made all that stuff too expensive — we leaned into the road itself, letting America reveal itself serendipitously. Since it cost a small fortune to be on the road, why not make it the focus of our trip?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: ‘It’s Anyone’s Guess’
description: Sid Sivakumar’s puzzle presents a wide range of possibilities.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is a connoisseur’s grid that will also please the rest of us, which is no surprise considering it comes from Sid Sivakumar. I did not pick up on the seriously low word count until I read the Constructor Notes — after all this time solving, I think I might have to try constructing a grid or two myself, to hone my eye — but I did note the cavalcade of artful crossings and tough clues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Where Can I Find a Great Travel Jacket?
description: A reader is looking for something light, wrinkle-proof and dressy-ish to take on trips.
content: Not only does such a garment exist, there is even a special name for it: a shacket! Like many newly relevant sartorial inventions (the megging, the jort), it is a hybrid garment (shirt plus jacket) well-suited for meeting contemporary needs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: John Merriman, Eminent Historian of France, Is Dead at 75
description: An indefatigable researcher, he wrote books about terrorists, anarchists, leftists and ordinary people and spent a lot of time in France’s archives.
content: John Merriman, a revered professor of history at Yale University who plumbed dozens of French governmental archives for the information that invigorated his fast-paced books about anarchists, terrorists, leftists and ordinary people in France, died on May 22 in New Haven, Conn. He was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: ‘A Mass Invasion of Privacy’ but No Penalties for Tim Hortons
description: A scathing report by four privacy commissioners found that the coffee and doughnut chain collected data on customers’ daily lives.
content: One way to figure out how deeply Tim Hortons is woven into Canada’s fabric is a cross-border comparison. If McDonald’s, perhaps its closest analogue in the United States, wanted to have the same per capita reach in that market as Tim Hortons boasts in Canada, it would have to roughly triple its 13,000-plus American outlets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Jennifer Medina
title: Should Biden Run in 2024? Democratic Whispers of ‘No’ Start to Rise.
description: In interviews, dozens of frustrated Democratic officials, members of Congress and voters expressed doubts about the president’s ability to rescue his reeling party and take the fight to Republicans.
content: Midway through the 2022 primary season, many Democratic lawmakers and party officials are venting their frustrations with President Biden’s struggle to advance the bulk of his agenda, doubting his ability to rescue the party from a predicted midterm trouncing and increasingly viewing him as an anchor that should be cut loose in 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: A Night on Governors Island? Be Prepared to Spend for It.
description: Though no one is allowed to live permanently on the island, a small number of people can stay there overnight during the summer — for a price.
content: This story is part of an occasional series exploring nightlife in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Five Decades, Three Generations of Runners, One All-Women’s Race
description: Julianne Grace “felt like a spectacle” when she lined up for her first New York Mini in 1975. Now she’s joined by her daughter and granddaughters.
content: Julianne Grace began running in 1971 after her husband encouraged her to give it a try. They started with a half-mile run. She hated it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: It Works for Sneakers. Now It’s for Baby PJs and Skateboards, Too.
description: A wide range of retailers are manufacturing excitement, and scarcity, with limited edition product “drops.”
content: Little Sleepies are pajamas and play clothes for children made out of bamboo cellulose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sebastian Modak
title: The Very Human Pleasure of Being Read To
description: From a Terry Pratchett fantasy to memoirs set in Northern Ireland and on a pig farm, these stories are most memorable for the voices telling them.
content: While many turn to audiobooks out of convenience, there is also a sense of comfort to be found in spending hours with a voice and a story. For me, audiobooks come with a generous helping of nostalgia; a harking back to bedtime stories and the warm fuzziness of being read to. Three recent audiobooks have stuck with me not just for their content, but also for the narrators’ delivery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Haiyun Jiang, Desiree Rios and Uli Seit
title: Photos From the Belmont Stakes
description: New York Times photographers capture images from the 154th Belmont, the last leg of the Triple Crown.
content: The 154th Belmont Stakes on Saturday came with no promise of a Triple Crown winner, but that wasn’t unusual. It’s a rare horse that can win the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes and still arrive at the Belmont in top form. Only 13 horses have won all three races.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Pence Aide Warned Against Blocking Electoral College Count, Memo Shows
description: Shortly before Jan. 6, Vice President Mike Pence’s chief counsel wrote that holding up the certification of the election results would violate federal law.
content: Former Vice President Mike Pence’s chief counsel laid out in a memo the day before Jan. 6, 2021, that the vice president would violate federal law if he bowed to pressure from President Donald J. Trump to interfere with the certification of Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By the Editorial Board
title: ‘We All Have a Duty to Ensure That What Happened on Jan. 6 Never Happens Again’
description: The hearings on the Capitol riot challenge all Americans to recommit to democracy.
content: On Thursday night, a congressional committee began an unflinching conversation with the citizens of this country about, in the words of the committee chair, Donald Trump’s last stand, his attempt to spur the enemies of the Constitution to subvert American democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Peter Lamborn Wilson, Advocate of ‘Poetic Terrorism,’ Dies at 76
description: His concept of a “temporary autonomous zone” became an inspiration for protests like Occupy Wall Street and for gatherings like Burning Man.
content: Peter Lamborn Wilson, a counterculture intellectual, anarchist, poet, musicologist and utopian who coined the term “temporary autonomous zone,” which became a cri de coeur for the organizers behind both Burning Man and Occupy Wall Street — as well as for ravers, cyberpunks and other late-20th-century antiestablishmentarians — died on May 23 at his home in Saugerties, N.Y. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and David Fahrenthold
title: Reforms Are Imposed on U.N. Agency That Made Questionable Investments
description: After a New York Times report revealed unusual investments putting tens of millions of dollars at risk, the board of the U.N.’s Office for Project Services demanded major changes.
content: After a series of puzzling financial decisions that put tens of millions of dollars at risk, the executive board of a little-heralded United Nations agency took the rare step on Friday of voting to swiftly enforce a series of reforms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall and Suhasini Raj
title: Protests Over Prophet Muhammad Comments Turn Deadly in India
description: Two young protesters were killed in eastern India on Friday amid demonstrations by Muslims across South Asia.
content: NEW DELHI — Two young demonstrators were killed on Friday in India’s eastern Jharkhand State amid protests across South Asia by Muslims angered by a comment from an official in India’s governing party that they believe profaned the Prophet Muhammad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: Moderna’s Covid Vaccine Is Effective in Children Under 6, F.D.A. Says
description: Outside experts will meet next week to decide whether to recommend that the agency authorize the vaccine for kids 6 months and older.
content: Moderna’s coronavirus vaccine for children under 6 is effective in preventing symptomatic infection without causing worrisome side effects, the Food and Drug Administration said on Friday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Casey Quackenbush
title: A Secret City With a Secret African American History
description: The U.S. government built Oak Ridge in 1942 to develop the world’s first atomic weapon.
content: This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: Why Students Are Choosing H.B.C.U.s: ‘4 Years Being Seen as Family’
description: Many in a generation that grew up with a Black president and Black Lives Matter are embracing Black colleges and universities.
content: SeKai Parker looked on last spring as her prep school classmates tearfully embraced and belted out in unison every word of a Kelly Clarkson song.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William J. Broad
title: Eavesdropping on the Secret Lives of Dolphins in New York Harbor
description: For two years, an array of six underwater microphones tracked the feeding noises of marine mammals newly prevalent in New York waters.
content: It’s a riddle. No one knows for sure why dolphins are being spotted more frequently and for longer periods in and around New York Harbor, the giant estuary where salty ocean tides mix with fresh water from the Hudson River.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez and Alejandro Cegarra
title: A Caravan of Migrants Is Heading Toward the U.S. Border
description: Some 6,000 migrants, many of them from Venezuela, set off from southern Mexico last week as leaders from across the Americas met in Los Angeles to discuss issues including migration.
content: Thousands of migrants set off from southern Mexico last week in one of the largest caravans seeking to reach the United States in recent years. The mass movement coincided with a recent meeting in Los Angeles, of leaders from the Western Hemisphere, where migration was a key focus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski, Ivan Nechepurenko and Emma Bubola
title: Here are the latest developments in the war in Ukraine.
description: Three and a half months into the war, it has become clear that some of the most intense barrages of sanctions ever meted out by the West — and the torrent of Western companies voluntarily leaving Russia — have failed to completely dismantle the Russian economy or spark a popular backlash against President Vladimir V. Putin.
content: Three and a half months into the war, it has become clear that some of the most intense barrages of sanctions ever meted out by the West — and the torrent of Western companies voluntarily leaving Russia — have failed to completely dismantle the Russian economy or spark a popular backlash against President Vladimir V. Putin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: DeSantis Event at Chelsea Piers Faces Backlash Over L.G.B.T.Q. Rights
description: The Florida governor who signed the so-called Don’t Say Gay bill is scheduled to speak at a site long connected to the gay rights movement.
content: For the second time this spring, a New York City institution is facing a backlash over a conservative Jewish conference, long in the planning, because of one of its featured speakers: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roy Furchgott
title: The Pralines, Pecan Log Rolls and Nostalgia Fueling the Stuckey’s Revival
description: The pandemic reinvigorated car travel and, with it, the market for snacks and Americana. Will it last?
content: In June 2020, having used her life savings to buy back the failing roadside franchise that bears her family name, Stephanie Stuckey was in a Marion, Ark., parking lot in tears. The Stuckey’s in front of her was beyond decrepit; it was disreputable. A storm had opened a hole in the signature teal tile roof, and the owners hadn’t bothered to repair it. Sobbing, she called her vice president and said, “I can’t even walk into this store.” Without missing a beat he replied, “Welcome to your empire.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: Recording India’s Linguistic Riches as Leaders Push Hindi as Nation’s Tongue
description: Ganesh Devy has spent decades documenting India’s hundreds of distinct languages. Up next: a 12,000-year history of India he hopes will help counter the government’s Hindu-first campaign.
content: DHARWAD, India — The task was gargantuan: assembling a team of more than 3,500 language specialists, academics and enthusiastic amateurs to determine just how many distinct languages still exist in India, a country of stunning linguistic diversity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: 2 Teens Drown in New York Waterway Known for Strong Currents, Police Say
description: The boys, both 13, were on a sandbar in Jamaica Bay before entering the water in an area known for dangerous currents and sudden drop-offs.
content: Two 13-year-old boys drowned on Friday after slipping into Jamaica Bay off a sandbar, the police said. With summer approaching and more people being drawn to the water, the deaths were a reminder of the danger posed by the bay’s strong currents and steep drop-offs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: Why We Still Haven’t Solved the Unpaid Internship Problem
description: Unpaid internships benefit schools and employers, but aren’t fair to college students footing their own tuition bills.
content: The president and vice president announced this month that they were going to pay their interns. The White House put out a news release. I think we were supposed to stand up and cheer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Dennis Jr
title: Civil Rights Activists Fought for America’s Democracy. They Should Be Honored as Veterans.
description: Those who fought for America’s democracy should be treated as the war heroes they are.
content: History books have called my father an activist, a community organizer, a freedom fighter, among other things. But they don’t use a phrase that my dad has used to describe himself: a war general.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Don Perkins, Star Dallas Running Back, Is Dead at 84
description: He rushed for 6,217 yards in 107 games with the Cowboys from 1961 to 1968 and ranks fourth on the team’s career list.
content: Don Perkins, a six-time Pro Bowl running back with the Dallas Cowboys in the 1960s, died on Thursday. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Donald Trump, American Monster
description: A man of pure narcissistic psychopathy feels no guilt and has no sense of the damage he does.
content: WASHINGTON — Monsters are not what they used to be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Akinmade Åkerström
title: A Social Media Takedown Is a Blessing in Disguise for Sweden
description: Social media users around the world fixated on the curious Swedish tradition of not automatically offering food to guests.
content: STOCKHOLM, Sweden — On a warm day in late May, life was humming along, punctuated by fika breaks, with pastries, coffee and conversation, when Sweden found itself thrust into the center of a global Twitter storm. Usually known for its generous social safety nets, latte papas and midsummer frolics, the Scandinavian nation was trending — and not in a good way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Entries for the week of June 6, 2022.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Here’s What You Need to Know About America’s Super-Hot Inflation
description: Inflation is a tricky problem, but it has a few clear causes and consequences, and policymakers are working to bring it to heel.
content: The government reported on Friday that consumer prices climbed 8.6 percent over the year through May, the fastest rate of increase in four decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Didn’t We Just Have This?
description: You’re not seeing double — there’s an echo in this Will Nediger puzzle.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Will Nediger is a professional crossword constructor from London, Ontario, who contributes regularly to The New Yorker and other outlets as well as The Times. He said, “I enjoy architecturally challenging constructions — like this puzzle, which was tricky to create, because the theme content had to be placed in a specific order.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Janetsky and María Silvia Trigo
title: Former Bolivian President Sentenced to 10 Years in Prison
description: The trial of Jeanine Añez, who took power after Evo Morales was ousted, has led to concerns about politicians’ use of the justice system to target opponents.
content: Jeanine Añez, the former president of Bolivia, was sentenced to 10 years in prison on Friday following accusations that she illegally took over the presidency after the resignation of her predecessor, Evo Morales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Why the Memory of Jan. 6 Can’t Prevent a Trump Resurgence
description: How an anti-Trump establishment undercuts itself.
content: There are two metrics for the success of the House’s Jan. 6 committee. One is within the committee’s control: A fair and comprehensive accounting of how far Donald Trump and his inner circle went in their effort to overturn the 2020 election, and how that effort interacted with mob violence, can serve future generations of Americans regardless of how it’s received today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard, Asmaa al-Omar and Laura Boushnak
title: Rumbling Through Modern Jordan, a Railway From the Past
description: Once an ambitious project to unite the Middle East, the antique Hejaz Railway is a relic of that bygone dream before wars, borders and more advanced modes of transport rendered its services obsolete.
content: AMMAN, Jordan — Astride century-old tracks that cut through the modern metropolis of Amman, a historic train blared a horn to announce its departure. That sound spurred families bearing bags of food, pots of coffee, coolers of soda, grills, hookahs and lots of children into action, scrambling up iron ladders to settle into the train’s wooden cars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: Days before his South Carolina primary, a G.O.P. congressman who voted to impeach Trump stands by his vote.
description: Representative Tom Rice is bracing for a tough runoff election against a Trump-backed challenger following Tuesday’s primary.
content: CONWAY, S.C. — Tom Rice, the South Carolina congressman who was one of 10 House Republicans to vote to impeach President Donald J. Trump after the Jan. 6 attacks, has a catchall term to describe the former president’s crusade against him: Trump’s Very Presidential Traveling Revenge Circus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: Stephen Curry’s Spectacular Night Fuels Key Win Over Celtics
description: Golden State desperately needed a win after losing two of the first three games in the N.B.A. finals. Curry’s 43 points on Friday got it done.
content: BOSTON — For two days, Golden State forward Draymond Green saw it in his teammate Stephen Curry. The fire Curry plays with isn’t always apparent to outsiders, but Green sensed that it was simmering within.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Katie Benner
title: Jan. 6 Committee Appears to Lay Out Road Map for Prosecuting Trump
description: The first prime-time hearing into the Jan. 6 attack confronted the fundamental question that has haunted Donald J. Trump since he left office: Should he be prosecuted in a criminal court?
content: He had means, motive and opportunity. But did Donald J. Trump commit a crime?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: England’s Traffic-Clogged North Bitter Over Stalled High-Speed Rail Plan
description: Transport problems are just one symptom of the economic neglect that has long hobbled the region, where growth, employment and health care mostly lag far behind the south.
content: BRADFORD, England — As Haniyya Ejaz boards her crowded morning train in the northern city of Bradford, an automated announcement tinged with a cheery Yorkshire accent chimes, “Welcome aboard this northern service to Leeds.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Saving Somalia’s Starving Babies
description: Doctors and nurses in Somalia are racing against time to save children from starvation because of the drought sweeping the country. In hospitals and clinics, here’s how medical workers are saving babies.
content: Doctors and nurses in Somalia are racing against time to save children from starvation because of the drought sweeping the country. In hospitals and clinics, here’s how medical workers are saving babies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: A Stalled High-Speed Line in North England
description: Transport problems have long hobbled northern England, and an ambitious rail project was meant to ease these woes. I went to the region to explore the initiative and to see how northerners felt after a portion of it didn't go as initially planned.
content: Transport problems have long hobbled northern England, and an ambitious rail project was meant to ease these woes. I went to the region to explore the initiative and to see how northerners felt after a portion of it didn't go as initially planned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Lyons
title: H.B.C.U. Students Show Us Their Campus Spirit
description: To capture the essence of life at an H.B.C.U., or historically Black college and university, eight Howard University photography students documented a meaningful part of campus culture.
content: To capture the essence of life at an H.B.C.U., or historically Black college and university, eight Howard University photography students documented a meaningful part of campus culture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: Pentagon Chief Warns China Over ‘Provocative’ Activity Near Taiwan
description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III said that the United States opposed any changes to the status quo between China and Taiwan, and that it would continue assisting Taiwan in maintaining self-defense capabilities.
content: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III said that the United States opposed any changes to the status quo between China and Taiwan, and that it would continue assisting Taiwan in maintaining self-defense capabilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden Announces Migration Deal with Latin American Leaders
description: The agreement commits the United States to taking 20,000 refugees from Latin America over the next two years, a small fraction of the migrants who typically try to cross the southern border each year.
content: The agreement commits the United States to taking 20,000 refugees from Latin America over the next two years, a small fraction of the migrants who typically try to cross the southern border each year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 11, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 11, 2022.
content: An article on Friday about Naasón Joaquín García, the head of the church La Luz del Mundo, who was sentenced to more than 16 years in prison for sexually abusing minors referred incorrectly to Alondra Ocampo. She is a woman.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Actors’ Roles: Should There Be a Limit?
description: Readers discuss a column by Pamela Paul about how actors have been criticized for playing people they do not resemble in real life.
content: To the Editor:
